Conveys the patient's wishes relating to the sensitivity of the drug information.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
An indication of sensitivity surrounding the related drug, and thus defines the required sensitivity for the detected issue.
Indicates that prescription is a 'PRN' (as needed) prescription and that doses to be consumed cannot be accurately calculated. This has important compliance implications.
To flag a prescription as PRN without specifying a condition, include the association but specify a null flavor for the Dosage Condition.
This sets the conditions for which a specific administration of the drug may be undertaken. Example: if headache persists for 2hrs or more 'take 2 tabs.
RepeatPattern.prn (true when present)
ZDP.13.6 (true when present)
Allows un-coded specifications of conditions in which the medication should be taken.

A free-form textual description of condition that must be met before the product may be administered to/by the patient.

Example: When pressure exceeds 150/90 - Take 2 tabs

Some drugs are more effective under specific body conditions and/or time of the day. This allows providers to ensure that administration of the drug is carried out at specific time and condition that they desire.
Indicates additional dosage instructions at the overall structured dosage level.
Structured dosage lines facilitate the checking of dosage appropriateness. It also allows for the formal calculation of days supply based on administration instructions and supplied quantity.

Dosage instructions may be given as textual information (as in Ad-hoc Dosage Instructions specified above) or as a structured set of dosage lines. This association allows for the specification of structured dosage lines.
Clearly expresses the order of each dosage line to ensure the correct dosage is given. Element is mandatory to ensure that dosage lines are specified and followed in the order intended.
Need examples to illustrate use of sequence lines with 'ANDs' and 'THENs'.

Indicates the order in which dosage lines should be performed. Ensures that each step of multiple and complex SIGs (e.g ramp up/down) is in the desired order. Dosage lines with the same sequence number should be performed in parallel. E.g. 2 tabs tid for 3 days (sequence 1) and then 1 tab tid for 4 days (sequence 2) E.g. 1 tab in the morning (sequence 1) and 2 tabs at bedtime (sequence 1)

Some drugs are more effective under specific body conditions and/or time of the day. This allows providers to ensure that administration of the drug is carried out at specific time and condition that they desire.

Indicates additional riders that may be put on a SIG. Each dosage line or the entire set of dosage lines may be augmented by a modifier that puts a rider on the administration. Examples of such modifiers include: At bed time, before breakfast, etc
CMET selected must be 'response' for query responses, non-response otherwise. Must use 'administrable' when capturing dispenses, 'orderable' otherwise

Allows the provider to have different instructions for different medications (in a package) within an overall therapy. For example, the dispensed drug could be Didrocal, and there will be a separate dosage instruction for each of the two drugs in the package. May also be used for Duo-Packs (e.g. vaginal products consisting of an ovule and a cream).

The drug only needs to be specified if the administration instruction corresponds to one part of the overall product. For example, referring to the administration of a particular product from a combo-pack
Identification of drug product that the instruction pertains to.
routeCode is mandatory and apporachSiteCode is required if not using SNOMED
- moodCode must be DEFN for drug definitions (such as monographs) - moodCode must be RQO for orders; - moodCode must be EVN for dispenses and recording of other medications
Allows providers to communicate intentions and to cross-check intended and actual methods of administration.
This comprises all specifications necessary for the dispensed product to be administered to/by the patient in a manner as intended by the prescriber.
Puts the class in context, and is therefore mandatory.

Indicates the context of the administration.

moodCode = RQO, for administration instruction on orders

moodCode = EVN, for administration instruction on dispenses

moodCode = DEF, for administration instruction on medication definition documents/references (typically, monographs).
Distinguishes between types of dosage administration and is therefore mandatory. Datatype is CD to allow for SNOMED codes.
For SNOMED this will pre-coordinate route, body site and potentially drug. For non-SNOMED, this will be a fixed value of DRUG.
Distinguishes types of dosage.

Allows the provider to verify the codified structured dosage information entered and ensure that the exploded instruction is consistent with the intended instructions.

Also useful in bringing back administration instructions on query responses.

This is mandatory as dosage instructions must always be available in rendered form.

A free form textual specification generated from the input specifications as created by the provider.

This is made up of either an 'Ad-hoc dosage instruction' or 'Textual rendition of the structured dosage lines', plus route, dosage unit, and other pertinent administration information specified by the provider.
Prescription.Admin istrationStartDate (Low)
Prescription.Admin istrationStopDate (High)
DispensedItem.expectedStartDate

Indicates the overall time boundaries in which the person is expected to take the drug. Denotes the reference point for calculating expected exhaustion date and quantity on hand.

Facilitates compliance checking.

Note: TID may be interpreted differently based on situation (e.g. based on schedules of a facility).
Frequently only the duration (width) component is specified. E.g. 100mg tid for 10 days. In that case, the start date is presumed to be the date the prescription was written
The time period (begin and end dates) within which the dispensed medication is to be completely administered to/by the patient. May differ from date prescription was issued.
Prescription.route
Compound.452-E8
RXR.1

Ensures consistency in description of routes. Provides potential for cross-checking dosage form and route. Route is an optional because it is pre-coordinated with SubstanceAdministration.code when using SNOMED.
This is the means by which the dispensed drug is to be administered to the patient.

Allows specificity when a drug can potentially be applied to different parts of the patien's body. Multiple repetitions are used when the product should be administered to multiple parts of the body. CWE is used because using a code system is not essential for understanding or analyzing the prescription. The attribute is optional because it can be pre-coordinated with SubstanceAdministration.code when using SNOMED.
A value denoting the body area where the medicine should be administered. E.g. 'Right Elbow', 'Left Ear'. When multiples sites are specified they should be treated as 'AND'.
ZPB3.5(denominator=1D)
Sets an upper boundary for the quantity of the drug to be administered over a specified period of time. Particularly useful for PRN medications.

This field can only capture maximum doses based on explicit time periods. Dosage maximums based on other constraints such as patient lifetime, menstrual cycles must be recorded using additional dosage instruction comments.

The maximum amount of the dispensed medication to be administered to the patient in a specified period of time. Examples include: per hour, 24-hr period (doses per day), 7 day period (doses per week), yearly.
Needed when the dosage unit is not expressed as part of the dose quantity (mg, mL) or implicit as part of the drug form (capsules, tablets). Examples are Puffs, Actuations, etc.

Identifies how the drug is measured for administration.

Specified when not implicit from the drug form (e.g. puff, inhalation, drops, etc.).
- moodCode must be DEFN for drug definitions (such as monographs) - moodCode must be RQO for orders; - moodCode must be EVN for dispenses and recording of other medications
Either an Ad-hoc Dosage Line or (Dosage Timing/Frequency + Dosage Range + possibly Dosage Rate) may be specified t one time }
Enables SIG instructions to be discretely specified. Also, supports scaling doses and parallel dose specification.
This information, along with the order/sequence of the dosage lines, constitutes the details of a structured dosage instruction.
Puts the class in context, and is therefore mandatory.

Indicates the context of the administration.

moodCode = RQO, for administration instruction on orders

moodCode = EVN, for administration instruction on dispenses

moodCode = DEF, for administration instruction on medication definition documents/references (typically, monographs).
DispensedItem.instruction
Prescription.instruction

Not all dosage instructions can easily be expressed in formal terms

Allows dosage instructions to be sent across as one string of information without breaking it up.
This field must not be used for components of the prescription that are coded elsewhere.(e.g. Coded Dosage Timing).
A free form description of how the dispensed medication is to be administered to the patient.
DosageItem.Duration(OuterInterval.Width)
DosageItem.StartDate(OuterInterval.Low)
RepeatPattern.PatternCode(PIVL - codes will need to be mapped to and from formal GTS expressions)
RepeatPattern.uncodedPattern (PIVL.originalText)
ZDP.13.2.1 (PIVL.period)
DP.13.2.2 (single time or list of times)
PID.13.3 (outer IVL<TS>.width)
PID.13.4 (outer IVL<TS>.low)
PID.13.5 (outer IVL<TS>.high)
Frequency
Together with the dose quantity, indicates the overall quantity of drug.

A structure describing the frequency (how often the drug is to be administered), offset (elapse time between administrations) represented by one line of dosage administration instruction. Includes the overall time-period the dosage instruction applies.
DosageItem.DosageRange
Dosage
Enables the checking of administration compliance that could results in fill-too-soon/fill-too-late contraindications. Supports circumstances where the dose can vary. (e.g. 1-2 tablets)
Where no range is needed, sending the same value in both the low and the high is the preferred solution.
This specifies the minimum and maximum amount of the medication to be taken during a single administration.
Required for intravenous administration
For intravenous and other such routes, this is the time period over which one dose is to be administered. The flow rate is determined by dividing the dose quantity by the Dosage rate.
- moodCode must be DEFN for drug definitions (such as as monographs) - moodCode must be RQO for orders; - moodCode must be EVN for dispenses and recording of other medications { x.; }
Adds further constraint or flexibility to the primary administration instruction.
This is a modifier for a specific dosage line or for the entire SIG. Examples are: On empty stomach, At breakfast, before bedtime, etc.
Puts the class in context, and is therefore mandatory.

Indicates the context of the administration.

moodCode = RQO, for administration instruction on orders

moodCode = EVN, for administration instruction on dispenses

moodCode = DEF, for administration instruction on medication definition documents/references (typically, monographs).

Allows for expression of non-codable qualifiers such as: 'on an empty stomach', 'add water' etc; which do not affect calculations of frequencies or quantity.

This attribute is marked as 'mandatory' as it is the only information that can be specified here.
A free form textual description of extended instruction regarding the administration of the drug.
Allows providers to specify administration constraints that are not frequency-related. . E.g. Take on waking, Take 1 hour before intercourse
The presence of this association indicates that the dosage line is "PRN" (as needed). If no condition is specified, the detailed condition and target time attributes may be omitted.
Indicates condition(s) that must be satisfied for the dosage instruction conveyed by a dosage line to be carried out.
Code must be fixed to DX if not using SNOMED
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Describes diagnosis-related indications
Identifies this measurement as a type of diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. It is set to CD because SNOMED codes may require post-coordination
For SNOMED, the complete diagnosis appears here. For non-SNOMED this should be a fixed value of "DX".
Identifies the type of diagnosis
Provides greater flexibility in specifying indication.
A free form description augmenting the specified diagnosis code.
Allows cross-checking the use of a therapy against its indication. Also allows analysis of best practices, etc. This attribute is optional because it is not used by SNOMED.
A coded form of the diagnosis that is the reason for the current action.
Code must be fixed to SYMPT if not using SNOMED
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Describes symptom-related indications
Indicates that this observation is expressing a symptom, and is therefore mandatory. It is set to CD because SNOMED codes may require post-coordination
For SNOMED, this will communicate the full symptom. For non-SNOMED this will be a fixed value of SYMPT
Identifies the category of symptom being communicated.
Provides greater flexibility in specifying indication.
A free form description to augment the specified symptom.
Allows cross-checking the use of a therapy against its indication. Also allows analysis of best practices, etc. The attribute is optional because it is not used for SNOMED.
A coded representation of the symptom that is the reason for the current therapy.
Must have at least one of code or text
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Describes indications that are not diagnosis or symptom-related (e.g. contrast agents)
Allows for coded representation of a non-condition based indication such as administration of a contrast agent for a lab test.
A code indicating some other action which is the reason for a therapy.
Provides ability to describe indication without labeling it a diagnosis or symptom. Attribute as free form text is the only information allowed.
A textual description of an indication not meant to be either diagnosis or symptom.

As a request, refers to the event to be acted upon or which has been acted upon.

As a response, may be used to indicate the identifier assigned to a created object.
References an existing event record by identifier.
Allows the event record to be uniquely referenced and is therefore mandatory.
The identifier assigned by the central system (EHR) to the Event record being referred to.

Ensures that the event to be acted upon pertains to the right patient.

This relationship is mandatory because the Patient must first be identified before an action can be taken on any event pertaining to the Patient.
Identity of the Patient whose event is being acted upon.

As a request message, refers to the order record to be acted upon or which has been acted upon.

As a response, may be used to indicate the identifier assigned to a created object.
References an existing Request or Order record by identifier.
Allows the order record to be uniquely referenced and is therefore mandatory.
The identifier assigned by the central system (EHR) to the Request or Order record being referred to.

Ensures that the order to be acted upon pertains to the right patient.

This relationship is mandatory because the Patient must first be identified before an action can be taken on any order pertaining to the Patient.
Identity of the Patient whose order is being acted upon.
Critical for auditing and for validating permissions and therefore mandatory.
Indicates the person responsible for the event that caused this message.
Value should always be AUT
The time a decision is made is a critical piece of audit information and is therefore mandatory.
The time the person responsible for the query made the decision for it to occur. This may be different than the time the time the query was actually performed.
May have ramifications for the audit trail and reliability of the information.
Indicates how the person who recorded the event became aware of it.. E.g. Verbal, written, fax, etc.
Digital signatures may be needed for authentication of message content. The attribute is marked as optional because it is not yet clear whether there is a use-case for this, or where it will be used.
Indicates the formal digital signature of the message content.
Key to understanding what action a message represents.
There may be constraints on the usage of the reasonCode attribute in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
Used for audit purposes and is therefore mandatory.
Queries cannot be retracted, so this event identifier does not need to be locally persisted.
A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
Allows identifying the reason for accessing information via a query.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Identifies why this specific query occurred.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
This should only be specified if different from the author.

Indicates the person responsible for entering the query into the system. Used when different from the person responsible for the request than actually running the query. E.g. Physician requests administrative assistant to print off a patient's medication profile.
Indicates a potential location for written records, and may also be important for authentication purposes.
This should only be specified if different from the location where the event was authored.
Indicates the location where the record of this event was entered into the EHR.
Indicates where paper records may be located, and may be important to determining authorization. The association is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the service delivery location where the event occurred.
initialQuantityCode must be populated if and only if initialQuantity is populated
Provides support for queries
Identifies the content desired within a query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
Unique number for this particular query.
There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations.

If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested. Regardless of the number specified here, the number of rows returned will never exceed the number of matching rows based on the query parameters.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed. Queries may raise errors related to data-access permissions, non-recognized identifiers, etc.
Identifies errors or warnings that were caused by the previous message or that are being managed as part of the current message.
Important to tracking permission and managing patient consent.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR. (E.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange.)

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize this access or update.

May also be used to override access to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis. That is, this message can provide the same functionality as the Consent message.

packageLocation.name: QUQI_MT120000CA
packageLocation.desc: Trigger Event Wrapper for Query Responses

annotation.text: Key to understanding what action a message represents.
There may be constraints on the usage of the reasonCode attribute in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
Used for audit purposes and therefore mandatory.
A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
Sometimes messages may be constructed and sent at a significantly different time than the query was actually processed.
Indicates when the query was performed. If not specified, the assumption is that the query was performed at the same time the message was constructed.
Usually used to indicate a reason why a query was unsuccessful or was not processed.
Indicates the reason for the response given
Links a query response to the query that invoked it, and provides information about the overall result-set (which may not have been completely returned as part of the response.)
Describes the results of a particular query.
A single query may involve multiple messages. (Multiple continuations.). This attribute links all messages related to the same query and is therefore mandatory.
The identifier of the query this response is related to.
Indicates whether the query was successful and is therefore mandatory
Indicates the overall result status of the query.
Indicates whether additional content exists that may need to be retrieved by query continuations and is therefore mandatory
The total number of matching rows found by the query. (This may differ from the number of rows actually returned.)
Provides a quick overview of the number of items without having to go through and count the data and is therefore mandatory.
The number of item repetitions returned in the current response.
Provides a means of evaluating the magnitude of the result and is therefore mandatory.
The number of item repetitions yet to be returned in the current response.
initialQuantityCode must be populated if and only if initialQuantity is populated
Provides support for queries
Identifies the content desired within a query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
Unique number for this particular query.

There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations. If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
Identifies errors or warnings that were caused by the previous message or that are being managed as part of the current message.
Provides information about the thing being created or modified.
If there are multiple subject items, the changes to all of them must be either accepted or rejected as a single action. I.e. One trigger event = 1 unit of work.
Indicates the item(s) being acted upon by this trigger event.
Authorization.Person
Authorization.signatory(PT)
Consent can be provided by the patient or representative or be overridden by a provider. It is important to know which occurred for audit purposes.
Indicates that the consent was provided by the patient or representative.
Verbal consents may trigger a higher level of auditing.
Indicates whether the patient's consent is written or verbal.
Authorization.signatory(PROV)
Clinical circumstances may demand that a patient's information be accessed without consent to ensure patient safety.
Indicates that information access was approved by a provider rather than a patient. I.e. This is an override rather than an actual consent.
Provides details about the consent
Indicates the type of information access consented to
If code is INFA, then InformDefinition must be present, otherwise it must be absent
One and only one of author1 (Consenter) and author2 (Provider) must be specified
If author2 (provider) is specified, reasonCode must be specified
Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.
Authorization.formNumber
Provides a traceable audit link between a physical consent form and its electronic record
A unique identifier for a specific consent for a patient.
Distinguishes what type of consent is being dealt with and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the type of consent being given: Information access or Information maintenance.
Must be either not present or non-null.

Primarily applies for global "participation" consent, when there is a need to track whether the patient has consented, not consented, or has not recorded a decision.

Because not all jurisdictions will track "participation" consent, this attribute is optional. In jurisdictions where it is supported, the element must always be valued as either true or false.
If true, indicates that consent has explicitly *not* been given.
Authorization.endTime (high)
Most consents are not open-ended, to ensure the patient retains a level of control
Indicates the time that the consent will expire. 'Low' is effective time and 'High' is end time.
Authorization.reason (mnemonic)
Authorization.comment (original text)
Important for audit purposes
Indicates a reason for overriding a patient's consent rules or accessing information without consent.
Allows assertion of who issued the consent.
Indicates that consent was granted by the patient themselves
Allows fine-grained control over the types of information access is granted to and who is granted access.
Describes the type of information access being consented to.
Indicates who is being authorized to receive the information, and is therefore populated.
Identifies the beneficiary of the consent as being a Provider or Service Location.

Different consents may need access to different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the consent applies to is critical to controlling access, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.
The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified.
Indicates the patient record the consent is associated with and is therefore mandatory.
The patient's record the consent is associated with.
Authorization.Person
Authorization.signatory(PT)
Indicates who is responsible for changing the keyword, and is therefore mandatory

To Create/Update/Remove the keyword, the Keyword message is used in tandem with the Consent CMET on the Trigger Event (Control Act) Wrapper i.e. To Create, the keyword attribute in the consent CMET contains a null value and the message payload will provide the new keyword value. To Update, the old keyword would be submitted in the consent CMET keyword attribute (and must match to the keyword on record), while the message payload will contain the new keyword value. To Remove, the old keyword is submitted in the consent CMET keyword attribute (and must match to the keyword on record), while the message payload will contain a null value which will replace the old keyword value on record.
Indicates that revision to the keyword was requested by the patient or representative.
ZKW.5
ZZZ.9
Allows patients to change their keyword. If explicitly set to null, removes the keyword for the identified record types. Because of this, the attribute is set to 'populated' and not mandatory.

The create/update/remove function is done in tandem with the use of the Consent CMET. To Create - the keyword in the consent CMET contains a null value and the message pa yload will provide the new keyword value To Update - the old keyword would be submitted in the consent CMET (and must match to the existing keyword), while the message payload will contain the new keyword value To Remove - the old kwyord is submitted in the consent CMET (and must match to the existing keyword), while the message payload will contain a null value which will replace the old keyword value
Indicate the keyword associated with a particular consent.
Allows a patient to control access to their health information. Provides authorization for providers to view patient information.
Information pertaining to a patient's secret password used to control access to his/her health information.
Authorization.dataType
Sometimes keywords are changed by the patient, sometimes by a patient representative.
Indicates that the keyword was changed by the patient themselves.

Different keywords may be needed to access different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the keyword applies to is critical, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.

The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified. Examples are: demographics, medications, lab, DI, etc

The keyword revisioning process may also involve revising the list of information types covered by the keyword.
Indicates the patient whose record the keyword is associated with, and is therefore mandatory.
Identification of the patient whose health information is governed by the keyword.

Allows the patient to selectively apply diffent keywords to different information categories.

At least one information category must be identified, thus this participation is mandatory.
Indicates the categories of information governed whose access is governed by the keyword.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
Value is required if not using SNOMED
At least one of Id or Value must be specified.
Provides evidence for recording the allergy/intolerance.
Indicates the specific allergy test that supports the recording of the allergy/intolerance.
Allows an allergy/intolerance test record to be directly referenced.
An identifier for a specific instance of an allergy/intolerance test.
Allows different kinds of allergy/intolerance tests to be distinguishable and is therefore mandatory. It uses the CD type to support SNOMED post-coordination.
A coded value denoting the type of allergy test conducted.
Allows providers to evaluate the currency of the test.
The date on which the allergy test was performed.

Allows other providers to evaluate the test. There is no point in associating an allergy test with unknown results with an allergy or intolerance however the element is optional because this information may be post-coordinated in the 'code' attribute using SNOMED.
A code indicating result of the allergy test.
Value is required if not using SNOMED
Reaction Assessment code must be fixed to RXNASSESS if not using SNOMED

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Communicates the relatedness assessment of the exposure to the reaction and is therefore mandatory. For SNOMED this will communicate the full assessment. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
For SNOMED this will include the actual assessment. For non-SNOMED, this should be fixed to RXNASSES.
Indicates the type of assessment being made
Creates the link between the exposure and the reaction. Because the details of the assessment will be communicated in the 'code' attribute for SNOMED, this element is optional.
This attribute will not be populated if using SNOMED. Otherwise it should have a fixed value of "RELATED".
Indicates whether the reaction is deemed to be related to the exposure.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.
Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
Communicates the cause of the adverse reaction.

Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.

Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.
Allows for drilling down to retrieve further information about the exposure
Identifier of the record or order that caused the reaction. This could be an identifier for a prescription, immunization, or other active medication record.
Helps evaluate the cause of the reaction.
The method by which the patient was exposed to the substance.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
The date on which the allergy/intolerance was reported.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Necessary component of a person's overall medication and clinical profile. Helps with drug contraindication checking.
A record of a patient's allergy or intolerance.

Allows for the separation of allergy and intolerance records. The type of condition is critical to understanding the record and is therefore mandatory. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
A coded value denoting whether the record pertains to an intolerance or a true allergy. (Allergies result from immunologic reactions. Intolerances do not.)
Allows providers to refute a previously confirmed or suspected allergy. The attribute is mandatory because it is essential to know whether a record is refuted or not.
An indication that the allergy/intolerance has been refuted. I.e. A clinician has positively determined that the patient does not suffer from a particular allergy or intolerance.
Allows providers to evaluate the relevance of a recorded allergy/intolerance. The status has a default value of 'active' and is therefore mandatory.
System must default the status to 'active'.
A coded value that indicates whether an allergy/intolerance is 'active' or 'completed' (indicating no longer active).
Allows providers to evaluate the period of relevance for the allergy/intolerance record.
The date on which the recorded allergy is considered active.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Denotes access restriction placed on the allergy or intolerance record. Methods for accessing masked allergy records will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.). The default confidentiality level is 'NORMAL'.

Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.

Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either 'confirmed' or 'suspected'.

An indication of the level of confidence/surety placed in the recorded information.

The two valid codes are:

- U (stated with uncertainty) -Specifies that the author of the act affirms the uncertainty of the act statement. In other words, they know that parts of the act statement are not certain or are inferred. An example of this is an inferred prescription where some order data is inferred from a supply event (i.e. dispense).

- N (stated with no assertion of uncertainty) - Specifies that the act statement is made without any explicit expression of certainty/uncertainty. This is the normal statement, meaning that it may not be free of errors and uncertainty may still exist. In healthcare, N is believed to express certainty to the strength possible.

An allergy or intolerance record is always used in drug contraindication checking whether the record is U or N.
Critical for identifying the allergy or intolerance. However, because the attribute is not used for SNOMED, it is optional.
Indicates the substance to which the patient is allergic
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded. Also, the code may sometimes be masked, in which case a "null flavor" must be specified.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.
Value is required if not using SNOMED
Reaction Code must be fixed to DX if not using SNOMED
At least one of Id or Value must be specified.
Allows for direct referencing of an adverse reaction record which was previously recorded.
An identifier assigned to the record of the adverse reaction.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.

The element is mandatory because it is essential to know for a given record whether the reaction occurred or not.
Indicates if there was an there was no adverse reaction when the patient was exposed to the agent to which an allergy/intolerance has been recorded.
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.
A free form description of the reaction.
Indicates when evidence of the condition first appeared. May also provide information on the duration of the reaction.
The date on which the reaction occurrence began.

Ensures consistency in tracking and categorizing the reaction type. Helps ensure that only proper allergies are categorized as allergy. The attribute is optional because it will not be used for SNOMED. The attribute is CWE because not all possible types of reactions are expressible by coded values.
Specifies the kind of reaction, as experienced by the patient.
Allows providers to determine appropriate managements for contraindications involving such medical conditions.
This is a ranking/ an assertion of the seriouness of the diagnosed/reported medical condition.
AllergyIntolerance.severity
Allows for sorting of allergy records. May influence whether contraindications must be managed. Because SNOMED pre-coordinates severity into 'code', the attribute is optional.
Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient.
Provides support for the agent identified as the allergen/intolerance source.
Indicates the agent that is believed to have caused the adverse reaction.
SeverityObservation must not be present if using SNOMED for ReactionObservationEvent.code
Allows providers to evaluate the significance of the allergy or intolerance. Because reaction severity is communicated as part of the code for SNOMED, this associaiton is optional.
An indication of the severity of the reaction.
SeverityObservation must not be present if ConditionEvent.code is using SNOMED
Useful for determining severity of an allergy/intolerance contraindication and the management of same. The association is optional because severity will be precoordinated into code for SNOMED.
Indicates the severity of the allergy/intolerance.
AllergyIntolerance.person
Ties the condition to a particular patient record, and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the person suffering from the allergy/intolerance.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this allergy/intolerance.
May help ascertain the severity of the condition, and provide direction for management. Also helps demonstrate the distinction between allergies and intolerances
Indicates a particular type of reaction experienced by the patient or testing performed on the patient which provides evidence for the existence (or non-existence) of the allergy/intolerance.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code is fixed to RXNASSESS if not using SNOMED
Indicates both the product and how related they are determined to be to the reaction.
This is a recording of the exposures and causality assessment deemed to be related to the reaction.

Communicates the relatedness assessment of the exposure to the reaction and is therefore mandatory. For SNOMED this will communicate the full assessment. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
For SNOMED this will include the actual assessment. For non-SNOMED, this should be fixed to RXNASSES.
Indicates the type of assessment being made
Creates the link between the exposure and the reaction. Because the details of the assessment will be communicated in the 'code' attribute for SNOMED, this element is optional.
This attribute will not be populated if using SNOMED. Otherwise it should have a fixed value of "RELATED".
Indicates whether the reaction is deemed to be related to the exposure.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.
Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
routeCode is required if not using SNOMED
Communicates the cause of the adverse reaction.

Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.

Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.
Allows for drilling down to retrieve further information about the exposure
Identifier of the exposure event that caused the adverse reaction. This could be an identifier for a prescription, immunization, or other active medication record.
Helps evaluate the cause of the reaction.
The method by which the patient was exposed to the substance.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
The date on which the adverse reaction was reported.
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded. Also, the code may sometimes be masked, in which case a "null flavor" must be specified.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.
Provides a human-readable name in circumstances where the agent is captured as code.
Indicates the name of the agent identified by MaterialKind.code
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code is fixed to DX if not using SNOMED

Useful in tracking reactions when it is not known precisely what product they are associated with and whether the reaction is due to an allergy or intolerance, a drug interaction or some other cause. Effectively gives a 'heads up' to clinicians using the drug or combination of drugs.
This is a record of an adverse reaction considered relevant to the patient's clincal record.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.

A free form description of the reaction.

This is a specific description of the reaction, as opposed to annotations on the reaction.

Annotations and text are quite different. Think of it from a user interface. Notes might be things like "patient didn't have the problem when the took the medication two weeks earlier" or "patient thinks it might have been related to the two bottles of scotch they drank the night prior", which aren't describing the reaction but are relevant to the reaction record
Indicates when evidence of the condition first appeared. May also provide information on the duration of the reaction.
The date on which the reaction occurrence began.

Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their adverse reaction data.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their adverse reactions. Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information. Valid values are: 'NORMAL' (denotes 'Not Masked'); and 'RESTRICTED' (denotes 'Masked'). The default is 'NORMAL' signifying 'Not Masked'.

Ensures consistency in tracking and categorizing the reaction type. Helps ensure that only proper allergies are categorized as allergy. The attribute is optional because it will not be used for SNOMED. The attribute is CWE because not all possible types of reactions are expressible by coded values.
Specifies the kind of reaction, as experienced by the patient.
Allows providers to determine appropriate managements for contraindications involving such medical conditions.
This is a ranking/ an assertion of the seriouness of the diagnosed/reported medical condition.
AllergyIntolerance.severity
Allows for sorting of reactions. May influence whether contraindications must be managed. Because SNOMED pre-coordinates this concept into code, the association is optional
Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient.
SeverityObservation must not be present if ReactionObservationEvent.code is using SNOMED

Useful for determining severity of an allergy/intolerance contraindication and the management of same. Because reaction severity is communicated as part of the code for SNOMED, this associaiton is optional.
Indicates the severity of the allergy/intolerance.
AllergyIntolerance.person
Ties the condition to a particular patient record, and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the person who suffered the adverse reaction.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this adverse reaction.
Allows linking the reaction to one or more drugs so that they can be flagged in the future when prescribed or dispensed.
Indicates the agent(s) that are suspected to have been involved in the adverse reaction.

Allows the recording provider the ability to designate certain conditions as chronic. This is especially useful in jurisdictions where the code scheme used for medical condition does not convey such information.

The association behaves as a mandatory boolean where the presence of the association represents 'true' while the absence represents 'false'.
If present, indicates that the recorded medical condition is deemed to be chronic.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
The date on which the medical condition was reported.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code is fixed to DX if not using SNOMED
Necessary component of a person's overall medication and clinical profile. Helps with contraindication checking.
A record of a patient's medical condition. Includes diseases, disabilities, pregnancy, lactation and other clinical conditions of interest.
Identifies this observation as reporting a medical condition and is therefore mandatory. When using SNOMED, the actual condition may be post-coordinated into this attribute, thus CD is used.
If SNOMED is used, the diagnosis will appear here. Otherwise, a fixed value of "DX" should be sent.
Indicates what kind of condition is being reported.
Essential to evaluating the relevance of the condition record. In some cases, it may not be known whether the condition still exists or not. Therefore the status is treated as 'populated'.
A coded value that indicates whether the condition is still impacting the patient. 'active' means the condition is still affecting the patient. 'completed' means the condition no longer holds
Allows providers to evaluate the period of relevance for the medical condition.

The date on which the condition first began and when it ended.

For ongoing conditions such as chronic diseases, the upper boundary may be unknown.

For transient conditions such as pregnancy, lactation, etc; the upper boundary of the period would usually be specified to signify the end of the condition.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Denotes access restriction placed on the medical condition record. Methods for accessing masked medical condition records will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.).

The default confidentiality level is 'NORMAL'.
This is the central piece of information in recording a condition. However because when using SNOMED the actual diagnosis will be sent in the 'code' attribute, this element is optional.
A code indicating the specific condition. E.g. Hypertension, Pregnancy.
Chronic Indicator must not be present if using SNOMED
AllergyIntolerance.person
Ties the condition to a particular patient record, and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the person affected by the condition
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to share un-coded free-form information about a condition.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this medical condition.
Allows for the selective retrieval of allergy/intolerance records based on the status of the record.
Indicates that the result set should be filtered to include only those allergy/intolerance records for the specified status. Valid statuses include: ACTIVE or COMPLETE.
Allows allergy/intolerance records to be selectively searched and retrieved.
A coded value indicating whether to return an allergy record or an intolerance record. The result set will be filtered to include only allergy records or intolerance records accordingly.
Useful in retrieving incremental changes to the patient's record.
Filters the query response to only include allergy/intolerance records which have been created or modified within the date-range specified.

Allows for the flexibility of omitting/including notes in the retrieval of information for allergy/intolerance data.

Because the attribute is boolean, it must explicitly indicate a 'TRUE' or 'FALSE', and thus it is mandatory.
Indicates whether or not notes attached to the allergy/intolerance records are to be returned along with the detailed information.
Root class for query definition
Defines the set of parameters that may be used to filter the query response
Used to confirm the identity of the patient for the query and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the date on which the patient was born.
Used to confirm the identity of the patient for the query and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the gender (sex) of the patient.
Allows filtering of result set by patient Id. This is a mandatory field because a patient must be specified for the query to be valid.
Identifier of the patient who is the subject of the allergy/intolerance query. Filter the result set to include only those records pertaining to the patient with this Id.
Allows filtering of result set by patient name. This is a mandatory field because a patient name must match the patient Id for the query to be valid.
The name of the patient who is the subject of the allergy/intolerance query. Filter the result set to include only those records pertaining to the patient with this name.
Allows allergy/intolerance records to be selectively searched and retrieved.
A coded value denoting a specific reaction. E.g. Code for 'rash'. The result set will be filtered to include only those allergy records or intolerance records pertaining to the specified reaction.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Provides evidence for recording the allergy/intolerance.
Indicates the specific allergy test that supports the recording of the allergy/intolerance.
Allows an allergy/intolerance test record to be directly referenced.
An identifier for a specific instance of an allergy/intolerance test.
Allows different kinds of allergy/intolerance tests to be distinguishable and is therefore mandatory. It uses the CD type to support SNOMED post-coordination.
A coded value denoting the type of allergy test conducted.
Allows providers to evaluate the currency of the test.
The date on which the allergy test was performed.

Allows other providers to evaluate the test. There is no point in associating an allergy test with unknown results with an allergy or intolerance however the element is optional because this information may be post-coordinated in the 'code' attribute using SNOMED.
A code indicating result of the allergy test.
Shows whether additional information is available on further drill-down
If present, indicates that there are notes associated with the allergy or intolerance.
AllergyIntolerance.authorizingProvider
AllergyIntolerance.authorizingPhysician
Identifies responsibility for accuracy and relevance of the information. This association reflects primary responsibility, and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the provider who reported the allergy or intolerance.
Identifies timing of allergy/intolerance for sorting and for audit purposes. Attribute is populated because the source of the data may not be through the 'record allergy/intolerance' interaction.
The date and time on which the allergy/intolerance record was created.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code must be fixed to RXNASSESS if not using SNOMED

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Communicates the relatedness assessment of the exposure to the reaction and is therefore mandatory. For SNOMED this will communicate the full assessment. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
For SNOMED this will include the actual assessment. For non-SNOMED, this should be fixed to RXNASSESS.
Indicates the type of assessment being made
Creates the link between the exposure and the reaction. Because the details of the assessment will be communicated in the 'code' attribute for SNOMED, this element is optional.
This attribute will not be populated if using SNOMED. Otherwise it should have a fixed value of "RELATED".
Indicates whether the reaction is deemed to be related to the exposure.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.
Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
Communicates the cause of the adverse reaction.

Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.

Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.
Allows for drilling down to retrieve further information about the exposure
Identifier of the exposure event that caused the adverse reaction. This could be an identifier for a prescription, immunization, or other active medication record.
Helps evaluate the cause of the reaction.
The method by which the patient was exposed to the substance.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
The date on which the allergy/intolerance was reported.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Necessary component of a person's overall medication and clinical profile. Helps with drug contraindication checking.
A record of a patient's allergy or intolerance.
Allows for direct referencing of an allergy/intolerance record when querying or performing updates and is therefore mandatory.
Unique identifier for an allergy/intolerance record.

Allows for the separation of allergy and intolerance records. The type of condition is critical to understanding the record and is therefore mandatory. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
A coded value denoting whether the record pertains to an intolerance or a true allergy. (Allergies result from immunologic reactions. Intolerances do not.)

Allows providers to refute a previously confirmed or suspected allergy. The attribute is mandatory because it is critical to know whether the record represents the refutation or affirmation of an allergy or intolerance.
An indication that the allergy/intolerance has been refuted. I.e. A clinician has positively determined that the patient does not suffer from a particular allergy or intolerance.
Allows providers to evaluate the relevance of a recorded allergy/intolerance. The status has a default value of 'ACTIVE' and is therefore mandatory.
System must default the status to 'ACTIVE'.
A coded value that indicates whether an allergy/intolerance is 'ACTIVE' or 'COMPLETE' (indicating no longer active).
Allows providers to evaluate the period of relevance for the allergy/intolerance record.
The date on which the recorded allergy is considered active.

Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.

The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.

Denotes access restriction placed on the allergy or intolerance record. Methods for accessing masked allergy records will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.). The default confidentiality level is 'NORMAL'.

Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.

Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either 'confirmed' or 'suspected'.

An indication of the level of confidence/surety placed in the recorded information.

The two valid codes are:

- U (stated with uncertainty) -Specifies that the author of the act affirms the uncertainty of the act statement. In other words, they know that parts of the act statement are not certain or are inferred. An example of this is an inferred prescription where some order data is inferred from a supply event (i.e. dispense).

- N (stated with no assertion of uncertainty) - Specifies that the act statement is made without any explicit expression of certainty/uncertainty. This is the normal statement, meaning that it may not be free of errors and uncertainty may still exist. In healthcare, N is believed to express certainty to the strength possible.

An allergy or intolerance record is always used in drug contraindication checking whether the record is U or N.
Critical for identifying the allergy or intolerance. Because it is not used for SNOMED, this element is optional.
Indicates the substance to which the patient is allergic

Indicates where records are likely kept for follow-up. May also be useful in understanding the context in which the allergy/intolerance was recorded. The location of entry should always be known, and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the service delivery location where the allergy was recorded.
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.
Value must be mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code must be fixed to DX if not using SNOMED

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.
Allows for direct referencing of an adverse reaction record which was previously recorded.
An identifier assigned to the record of the adverse reaction.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.

The attribute is mandatory because it is essential to know whether the reaction occurred or not.
Indicates if there there was an adverse reaction when the patient was exposed to the agent to which an allergy/intolerance has been recorded.
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.
A free form description of the reaction.

If present, indicates that the recorded medical condition is deemed to be chronic.
